newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Feb 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Feb 13.

text.p: The following is a summary of major stories in leading South Korean newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (822) 727-5649. Fax: (822) 727-5666.

- Two high-ranking North Korean officials have asked to defect to South Korea. Hwang Jang-yop, a senior advisor to North Korean leader Kim Jong-il and secreatary of the ruling Workers' Party in charge of foreign affairs, and his assistant, Kim Dok-hong, requested asylum in a South Korean embassy in Beijing on Wednesday.

- State prosecutors on Wednesday summoned ruling New Korea Party lawmaker, Hwang Byung-tai, and Home Affairs Minister, Kim Woo-suk, for questioning over their possible roles in releasing preferential bank loans to the Hanbo Group.
- Prime Minister Lee Soo-sung reportedly offered to resign during a cabinet meeting on Tuesday to assume responsibility over the Hanbo scandal.

- Home Affairs Minister Kim Woo-suk tendered his resignation to Prime Minister Lee Soo-sung on Wednesday before appearing at the Prosecutor-General's Office in Seoul for questioning over the Hanbo loan scandal.
